trial_identification.studytitle: To compare the effect of meals rich in thermally oxidised polyunsaturated fat and saturated fat on circulating numbers of endothelial microparticles
trial_identification.scientifictitle: To compare the effect of meals rich in thermally oxidised polyunsaturated fat and saturated fat on circulating numbers of endothelial microparticles

interventions.interventions: Administer meals rich in (a) thermally oxidised polyunsaturated sunflower oil, (b) unoxidised native sunflower oil, (c) cream. The meals will be administered at the rate of one per week and they will be given in random order. The total duration of the study will be 3 weeks.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in numbers of endothelial microparticles in the blood during 3 hour postprandial period.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: The outcome will be measured at 1 h and at 3 h after the meals.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Changes in markers of oxidative stress including plasma peroxides and nitrotyrosine.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: These variables will be measured at baseline and 1 h and 3 h after the meals.

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Serious illnesses, smoke cigarettes, taking medications or antioxidant supplements.

trial_design.concealment: Allocation schedule held by independent person
trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation of each individual to one of 6 meal sequences using randomisation table from a statistics book.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Otago Medical Research Foundation Inc PO Box 1245 Dunedin New Zealand

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Otago Medical Research Foundation Inc PO Box 1245 Dunedin New Zealand
Otago Medical Research Foundation Inc PO Box 1245 Dunedin New Zealand

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: University of Otago PO Box 56 Dunedin New Zealand

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Fatty fast food meals markedly and acutely increase circulating numbers of endothelial cell microparticles (EMPs) that are a marker of endothelial damage. These meals are usually rich in saturated fat and oxidized lipids that may adversely affect the vascular endothelium. Our study aims to compare the effect of ingesting heated polyunsaturated fats (PUFA) enriched in oxidized lipids, and unheated PUFA and saturated fat on circulating number of EMPs in healthy subjects. The findings of the study may indicate whether dietary advice that includes increased PUFA consumption and use in cooking needs to be modified.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Sutherland WHF, de Jong SA, Hessian PA, Williams MJA. ingestion of native and thermally oxidized polyunsaturated fats acutely increases circulating numbers of endothelial microparticles. Metabolism 2010; 59: 446-453.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Medicine Section Dunedin Hospital-Lower South Reginal Ethics Committee
